Liquid-Liquid Equilibria (picmol.thermo_model)¶

picmol.thermo_model.spinodal_fn(z, Hij)[source]¶

Calculates mole fractions where the Hessian of the Gibbs mixing free energy is zero, indicating spinodal points.

Parameters:

  • z (numpy.ndarray) – mol fraction array with shape (number of compositions, number of components).

  • Hij (numpy.ndarray) – determinant of Hessian matrix of the Gibbs mixing free energy.

Returns:

mol fractions of the spinodal curve. Returns an array of shape (2, number of components) for binary mixtures or None if fewer or more than two spinodal points are detected (excluding the first and last 5 points).

Return type:

numpy.ndarray or None

picmol.thermo_model.binodal_fn(num_comp, rec_steps, G_mix, activity_coefs, solute_idx=None, bi_min=-inf, bi_max=inf)[source]¶

Calculates mole fractions of the coexistence curve (binodal) using the convex envelope method (picmol.models.cem.CEM), which applies the isoactivity criterion.

Parameters:

  • num_comp (int) – number of components in the mixture.

  • rec_steps (int) – spacing for the discretization of the composition space.

  • G_mix (numpy.ndarray) – Gibbs mixing free energy array.

  • activity_coefs (numpy.ndarray) – array of activity coefficients for each component at each composition in the discretized space.

  • solute_idx (int, optional) – index of the solute component for reporting mole fractions (only relevant for binary systems).

  • bi_min (float, optional) – lower bound for mole fractions to be considered for binodals. Defaults to negative infinity.

  • bi_max (float, optional) – upper bound for mole fractions to be considered for binodals. Defaults to positive infinity.

Returns:

for binary systems, returns a tuple of two floats representing the minimum and maximum binodal mole fractions of the solute. Returns an array for multicomponent systems. Returns (np.nan, np.nan) if no valid binodal points are found for binary systems.

Return type:

tuple[float, float] or numpy.ndarray or tuple[np.nan, np.nan]

picmol.thermo_model.calculate_saxs_Io(z, molar_vol, n_electrons, Hij, T)[source]¶

Estimate the small-angle X-ray scattering (SAXS) zero-angle intensity, \(I_0\) (cm-1), as a function of temperature and composition.

The zero-angle scattering intensity is calculated using the formula:

\[I_0 = r_e^2 \left(\frac{\partial\rho}{\partial x}\right)^2 S_0\]

where the electron density contrast, \(\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial x}\), is given by:

\[\frac{\partial \rho}{\partial x} = N_A\sum_{i=1}^{N-1} \frac{N_i^e - N_n^e}{\overline{V}} - \overline{N^e}\left(\frac{V_i - V_N}{\overline{V^2}}\right)\]

and the structure factor at zero angle, \(S_0\), is:

\[S_0 = \frac{k_b T\overline{V}}{|H^x|}\]

The average molar volume, \(\overline{V}\), and average number of electrons, \(\overline{N^e}\), are calculated as:

\[\overline{V} = \sum_i^n x_i V_i\]
\[\overline{N^e} = \sum_i^n x_i N_i^e\]

where:

  • \(r_e\) is the electron radius.

  • \(N_A\) is Avogadro’s number.

  • \(N_i^e\) is the number of electrons in component \(i\).

  • \(V_i\) is the molar volume of component \(i\).

  • \(\overline{V}\) is the average molar volume of the mixture.

  • \(\overline{N^e}\) is the average number of electrons in the mixture.

  • \(|H^x|\) is the determinant of the Gibbs mixing free energy Hessian.

  • \(k_b\) is the Boltzmann constant.

  • \(T\) is the temperature.

Parameters:

  • z (numpy.ndarray) – mol fraction array with shape (number of compositions, number of components).

  • molar_vol (numpy.ndarray) – array of molar volumes for each component.

  • n_electrons (numpy.ndarray) – array of the number of electrons for each component.

  • Hij (numpy.ndarray) – Hessian matrix of the Gibbs mixing free energy.

  • T (float) – temperature (K)

Returns:

array of the zero-angle SAXS intensity, \(I_0\), for each composition.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

picmol.thermo_model.Tc_search(smiles: list, lle_type=None, Tmin=100, Tmax=500, dT=5, unif_version='unifac')[source]¶

Calculates the critical temperature (K) for a binary system using the UNIFAC model. The critical temperature is identified by finding the temperature at which spinodal points appear (Hessian of Gibbs mixing free energy becomes zero). The calculation can be optimized by specifying the type of LLE.

Parameters:

  • smiles (list) – list of SMILES representations of the two molecules in the binary system.

  • lle_type (str, optional) –

    type of liquid-liquid equilibrium transition. Options are:

    • ’ucst’: Upper critical solution temperature (critical temperature is the maximum on the phase diagram).

    • ’lcst’: Lower critical solution temperature (critical temperature is the minimum on the phase diagram).

  • Tmin (float, optional) – minimum temperature (K) for the search. Required for lle_type='lcst' or None. Defaults to 100 K.

  • Tmax (float, optional) – maximum temperature (K) for the search. Required for lle_type='ucst' or None. Defaults to 500 K.

  • dT (float, optional) – temperature step (K) for the search when lle_type is None. Defaults to 5 K.

  • unif_version (str, optional) –

    version of the UNIFAC model to use. Options are:

    • ’unifac’: Original UNIFAC.

    • ’unifac-lle’: Updated parameters for LLE.

    • ’unifac-il’: Includes support for ionic liquid molecules.

Returns:

The critical temperature (K). Returns np.nan if the critical temperature cannot be found.

Return type:

float or np.nan

class picmol.thermo_model.ThermoModel(model_name: str, KBIModel, Tmin=100, Tmax=400, dT=10)[source]¶

Calculates Gibbs mixing free energy and related mixing properties as a function of temperature for LLE analysis.

This class provides a framework for applying various thermodynamic models to analyze LLE in mixtures. It supports both binary and multicomponent systems, depending on the chosen thermodynamic model. The class initializes based on a selected model name, a KBI (Kirkwood-Buff Integrals) model object, and a temperature range for analysis.

Parameters:

  • model_name (str) –

    thermodynamic model to implement. Available options include:

    • ’quartic’: Numerical model using a 4th order Taylor series expansion (picmol.models.numerical.QuarticModel). Supported for multicomponent mixtures.

    • ’uniquac’: UNIQUAC (Universal Quasi-Chemical) thermodynamic model (picmol.models.uniquac.UNIQUAC). Supported for multicomponent mixtures.

    • ’unifac’: UNIFAC (Universal Functional-group Activity Coefficients) thermodynamic model (picmol.models.unifac.UNIFAC). Supported for multicomponent mixtures.

    • ’fh’: Flory-Huggins thermodynamic model (picmol.models.fh.FH). Supported for binary systems only.

    • ’nrtl’: NRTL (Non-Random Two-Liquid) thermodynamic model (picmol.models.nrtl.NRTL). Supported for binary systems only.

  • KBIModel (KBI) – KBI class object containing Kirkwood-Buff integrals and related data. This object provides information about the mixture components and their interactions.

  • Tmin (float, optional) – minimum temperature (K) for the temperature scaling analysis. Defaults to 100 K.

  • Tmax (float, optional) – maximum temperature (K) for the temperature scaling analysis. Defaults to 400 K.

  • dT (float, optional) – temperature step (K) for the temperature scaling analysis. Defaults to 10 K.

run()[source]¶

Performs temperature scaling analysis to estimate Gibbs mixing energy, phase diagram, and calculate SAXS I0 values.

This method iterates over the defined temperature range to calculate thermodynamic properties relevant for LLE. It distinguishes between binary and multicomponent systems to apply appropriate calculation methods.

Attributes (after running this method):

  • GM (kJ/mol): Gibbs mixing energy as a function of temperature and composition.

  • det_Hij: determinant of Hessian of Gibbs mixing energy with respect to composition.

  • x_sp: mol fractions at spinodal compositions as a function of temperature.

  • x_bi: mol fractions at binodal compositions as a function of temperature.

  • v_sp: volume fractions at spinodal compositions as a function of temperature.

  • v_bi: volume fractions at binodal compositions as a function of temperature.

  • GM_sp (kJ/mol, binary only): Gibbs mixing energy at spinodal compositions.

  • GM_bi (kJ/mol, binary only): Gibbs mixing energy at binodal compositions.

  • I0_arr: Small-Angle X-ray Scattering (SAXS) zero-angle scattering intensity as a function of temperature and composition.

  • x_I0_max: Widom line compositions in mole fraction as a function of temperature.

  • v_I0_max: Widom line compositions in volume fraction as a function of temperature.

The calculated results are stored as attributes of the ThermoModel object.

property T_values¶
Returns:

np.array of temperature values (K) for scaling

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

class picmol.thermo_model.UNIFACThermoModel(smiles: list, mol_names: list, solute_idx=0, Tmin=100, Tmax=400, dT=10, save_dir=None, unif_version='unifac')[source]¶

Performs temperature scaling for LLE analysis using the UNIFAC model.

This class is designed for purely predictive thermodynamic modeling based solely on the SMILES strings of the mixture components. It calculates Gibbs mixing free energy and related mixing properties as a function of temperature.

Parameters:

  • smiles (list) – list of SMILES strings for each component in the mixture.

  • mol_names (list) – list of names for each component in the mixture.

  • solute_idx (int, optional) – index of the solute component in the smiles and mol_names lists. Defaults to 0.

  • Tmin (float, optional) – minimum temperature (K) for the temperature scaling analysis. Defaults to 100 K.

  • Tmax (float, optional) – maximum temperature (K) for the temperature scaling analysis. Defaults to 400 K.

  • dT (float, optional) – temperature step (K) for the temperature scaling analysis. Defaults to 10 K.

  • save_dir (str, optional) – directory to save output files (not currently used in the provided code). Defaults to None.

  • unif_version (str, optional) – UNIFAC version to use (e.g., ‘unifac’, ‘unifac-lle’, ‘unifac-il’). Defaults to ‘unifac’.

run()[source]¶

Performs temperature scaling analysis using the UNIFAC model.

This method calculates Gibbs mixing energy, spinodal and binodal compositions as a function of temperature. It distinguishes between binary and multicomponent systems to apply the appropriate calculation methods. The results are stored as attributes of the UNIFACThermoModel object.

property num_comp¶
Returns:

number of components in the mixture.

Return type:

int

property T_values¶
Returns:

array of temperature values (K) used for scaling.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

compute_rdkit_properties()[source]¶

Computes molecular properties using RDKit.

This method calculates molecular weight, density, molar volume, number of electrons, and molecular charge for each component based on their SMILES strings.

Returns:

dicstionary of molecular properties by molecule

Return type:

dict

property mol_wt¶
Returns:

molar masses of the components from compute_rdkit_properties() function.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

property density¶
Returns:

densities of the components from compute_rdkit_properties() function.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

property molar_vol¶
Returns:

molar volumes of the components from compute_rdkit_properties() function.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

property n_electrons¶
Returns:

number of electrons for each component from compute_rdkit_properties() function.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

property mol_charge¶
Returns:

molecular charges of the components from compute_rdkit_properties() function.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray
